Cyberstalking has become more prevalent in recent years, and it is likely to continue to increase as technology becomes more sophisticated, and the use of the internet becomes more prevalent. However, law enforcement agencies are taking steps to keep up with the evolving methods used by cyberstalkers.

Many law enforcement agencies have developed specialized units focused on investigating cybercrime, including cyberstalking. These units employ investigators who have specialized training in digital evidence handling, cyber forensics, and other technological aspects of cybercrime investigation. Furthermore, law enforcement agencies are working together to share knowledge and resources to combat cybercrime and to develop international policies and agreements that help combat cyber stalking.

Additionally, advancements in technology and artificial intelligence (AI) can help law enforcement agencies quickly analyze and detect potential cybercrime activity before it happens. For instance, machine learning algorithms can automatically track and flag activities like online bullying, harassment, or stalking on social media platforms.

However, as technology continues to evolve, cyberstalkers will adapt as well, using new technologies and tactics to evade law enforcement. Law enforcement agencies must continuously evolve and stay current with evolving technology and have the necessary resources and know-how to identify and thwart cyberstalking. Consequently, continued funding and training of law enforcement personnel will be critical in keeping up with the changing landscape of cybercrime.
